history.content:
Check http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/exams#ac12367 for all AP score credit (assuming you are EECS as you tagged this post).

4 in BC does get you out of both Math 1A and 1B.  If you feel confident, you can go straight to Math 53 (multivariable calculus), but I would consider taking Math 1B, because you do probably don't want to go into Math 53 if you are shaky in calculus.  Also the official guide recommends "Students with a score of 4 should take Math 1B."

children.subject: Just to be clear, math at Berkeley is much different than math in high school - even AP. I applaud your confidence in your mathematical ability, but as general advice, don't think Berkeley will be as much of a cake walk as was AP.
I realize Berkeley is a top school in the nation and that high school is a joke. I'm doing EE16A/CS61A in the summer and it's pretty difficult, so definitely won't be slacking off nearly as much :)

Unpopular advice here: definitely skip Math 1B, a lot of people cite how much harder berkeley math is than HS, but when it comes down to it 1A and 1B are weeder classes so you should avoid at all costs and study them on your own. I highly recommend you look at previous finals and such to get a feel for how hard exams can be (you should be scoring around a 70% at least)
That's not unpopular advice; it's actually much common advice than to retake 1B.

Replying to Levi:

Normally I would recommend most students skip Math 1A and 1B as well. I agree that Berkeley lower division math classes are not terribly difficult (personally I found them easy).

However if you got a 4 on the AP calculus BC exam, it have serious qualms that you will do well in the following math classes.  I say this because AP Calculus BC is one of the easiest AP exams and has the highest percentage of students earning 5 on the exam.  In 2016, almost 50%.  If you got a 4 on the exam, frankly I think your calculus fundamentals are potentially very weak, at least by Berkeley standards.  Compare to AP Chemistry, where the 5 rate is under 10%.

Additionally, I think 1AB have additionally topics not covered by AP exams.  For example, in my Math 54 class, my GSI occasionally brought up topics from 1B, which he had previously taught, and no one knew what he was talking about, because most of the students skipped out with AP.    While these additional topics are not too hard to catch up on, its just even more to handle.

While I think you could get by skipping directly into Math 53, which is the continuation in a standard EECS math track, I highly doubt you will be able to fully grasp the concepts and do very well.

Not sure if Anon above is same as OP, but if special circumstances caused you to get a 4, I'm not sure how to judge your situation.

That being said, I believe there are sample tests on the Berkeley Engineering or EECS website that test readiness to skip out of 1AB.  If you can't find those, you could also look at https://tbp.berkeley.edu/courses/math/1B/

Hi Anon replying to Levi:

I'm the OP, as well as the creator of this thread. The cutoff for a 5 in AP Calculus BC is 60%. The thing is, for multiple choice I probably scored high, but didn't do well on the free response because I had next to no knowledge on series (which is half of the "C" part in Calc BC) and because I had tried to cram myself to learn the material in 2 days and all-nightered for the test, I was very unprepared to deal with the free response. It was during a tumultuous time where the week prior I was working on a computer vision project, and had other family issues at the time.

I did get a 5 on the AB subscore, so this leads me to believe that just the series component was my issue.

Advisors will often advise you against skipping 1A /1B but honestly it's to your benefit if you can skip them. If you want to learn calculus rigorously Math 104 ( which I thought was very interesting although challenging) does that anyways, and that's apparently the part many students struggle with in Math 1A.

I could probably study up the rest of Series in my own time; I took AP Calculus BC with no knowledge of series and I had tried to study the whole curriculum in 2 nights. 

Thanks for your reply.

history.content: Please note that this is tagged for EECS students. LSCS students need a 5 to waive out of math 1B with AP BC Calc.
Will this waive the Math 1B requirement or should I be taking 1B?
history.subject: 4 on Calculus BC

history.content: Will this waive the Math 1B requirement or should I be taking 1B?
history.subject: 4 on Calculus BC
